title: Journalism in the Digital Age
headline: Learn about the risks and opportunities journalists and bloggers face, by using digital resources in their content.
description: In this free course in online journalism in the digital age you will learn how journalists and bloggers use digital resources in their content. What risks and opportunities do journalists and bloggers face? This course will teach you how to use images, audio, and video in your content and how to provide your content safely and effectively. Check out this short course today, and bring your journalistic skills to the next level.
courseDescription:
In this course you will learn about the risks journalists and bloggers face working online, such as security, malware, hacking and privacy and how dangers and threats can be addressed through awareness, training and networking. You will study how bad actors can access and use information though surveillance, hacking, phishing and viruses. Journalists' sources and information can be compromised through censorship, defacement, disinformation and intimidation.

In addition, in this course, you will examine how editors plan for and use digital content. You will see how structure, interviews and timing are essential elements of TV, radio and online news packages. The course shows you how to utilise the correct video footage and media clips. Also in this course, you will learn the importance of knowing your audience and providing for their needs. Conducting research, surveys and usability studies with your audience provides crucial feedback regarding your product and how you are providing it.

This free course aims to make it easy to learn about the risks and opportunities journalists and bloggers face, by using digital (images, audio, video etc.) resources in their content and how they provide such content safely and effectively. These lessons will be of great benefit to media professionals, and to any student who would like to learn more about the skills required for working as a professional journalist. So, check out this short 3 hour course today, and bring your journalistic skills to the next level.

Start Course Now

• Module One Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Explain the classification of journalists.
    • Discuss the digital challenges facing journalists.
    • Describe the different types of online attacks.
    • Outline the main types of surveillance technology.
    • List the main digital security principles.

    • As journalism moves into the digital space,
      it will continue to benefit from expanding access to information, audiences, and publishing tools that new technologies offer. 

      Journalism is generated, processed and disseminated through electronic means – particularly digital. In today’s global multimedia environment, journalism can be practiced in a multimillion-dollar newsroom or from one’s bedroom. 

      At the same time, there are new threats.

    • Wherever it takes place, journalism often involves enormous risk to those producing it and their sources, particularly where its output challenges power or brings to light information that other actors seek to conceal.

      Those who practice journalism may attract attacks because of the important role they play, and it is because of this role that they also particularly merit protection. 

      They need to be safe and free to provide opportunities for the expression of opinions and information, monitor and shed light on government and corporate operations, and encourage accountability.

    • There are not always special provisions that protect journalistic communications from being collected or assessed.  

      As more content and metadata (information generated as one uses technology) is collected and stored, the picture of a journalist and his or her sources becomes clearer.

      By analyzing the metadata of time, place and frequency of communication, it is possible to identify the individuals involved in a particular journalistic exposé.

      According to a recent statement by several international organizations, to the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights: “The historical distinction between data about an individual’s communications and the content of his or her communications has become insignificant. As data becomes more and more revelatory, either in isolation or when paired with other data, it is no longer appropriate to subject communication data to lower thresholds, or consider its collection and processing a less invasive practice than interception of content. Communications data can now reveal equally sensitive information as communications content, and must enjoy equal protection under human rights law.”

  • Lesson Summary

    • The interconnectedness of Internet and mobile technologies, has enabled everyday citizens to participate in journalism. 
    • As the number of online journalists and content providers has increased, so have attacks against them.
    • Attacks against online journalists and content providers include: hacking of accounts; spying; monitoring of on and off-line activities; information interference; property theft and damage; censorship; arrest and detention.
    • Many independent bloggers, freelancers and citizen journalists do not have the resources for secure technology and resort to less secure open-source options.
    • Digital protection, security awareness and training for journalists and consumers, is becoming more widespread and needs to increase further. 
    • Political, military, security, intelligence, business and other organisations need to play a much more active role in the protection of free speech, information and personal data.
    • Hackers have found new ways to cause harm, including via social media and mobile devices. 
    • Journalists and their sources need to consider using secure encryption technologies. 
    • Digital threats are a serious concern, because they may be a precursor to real physical attacks against journalists and bloggers.

    • Many new media analysts have suggested that every reporter should have a blog (web log).

      That may not be feasible, but scores of successful journalist blogs are currently online, allowing the blogger/reporter to cultivate a community with readers, to test ideas, receive feedback and publish in the timeliest manner possible.

      A good blog helps a blogger/journalist enhance his or her authority on a beat by adding the ability to publish information outside of the traditional news cycle.
      Many new media analysts have suggested that every reporter should have a blog (web log).

      A good blog helps a blogger/journalist enhance his or her authority on a beat by adding the ability to publish information outside of the traditional news cycle.
    • The rules for blogs are different to traditional print and broadcasting. You can play off other information you find online, even linking to stories and other blogs that are related to the topic.

      A good blog is an ongoing conversation. It is facilitated by you, but, if it works, it may be dominated by your audience.

      If that happens, you win, the news organization wins and, most importantly, the readers win.

    • Good graphics add to the visual appeal of the newspaper, attract readers’ attention, and make stories more understandable. They help reporters’ stories, rather than take away from them. 

      Every graphic must have a purpose. Filling empty space is not a sufficient reason for using a graphic. 

      A graphic should enhance the reader or viewer’s understanding of the story, which means the editor must fully understand the story before designing or choosing a graphic to go along with it. 
      Good graphics add to the visual appeal of the newspaper, attract readers’ attention, and make stories more understandable. They help reporters’ stories, rather than take away from them. 

      Every graphic must have a purpose. Filling empty space is not a sufficient reason for using a graphic. 

      A graphic should enhance the reader or viewer’s understanding of the story, which means the editor must fully understand the story before designing or choosing a graphic to go along with it. 
    • Graphic artists usually produce the visual images. The role of the editor is to conceptualize the graphic, find the information it should contain or illustrate, and ascertain its accuracy. 

      Graphics can convey basic facts or illustrate a process. Imagine you are reporting on air pollution in your country. A map could be used to show where the air is most unhealthy. An illustration could be used to show how air pollution affects the lungs. Both types of graphics work just as well for broadcast as they do for print.

      Whatever the medium in which it will be used, avoid graphics that are crammed with too much information. The reader or viewer should be able to look at the graphic and take away one basic idea. 
      Graphic artists usually produce the visual images. The role of the editor is to conceptualize the graphic, find the information it should contain or illustrate, and ascertain its accuracy. 

      Graphics can convey basic facts or illustrate a process. Imagine you are reporting on air pollution in your country. A map could be used to show where the air is most unhealthy. An illustration could be used to show how air pollution affects the lungs. Both types of graphics work just as well for broadcast as they do for print.

      Whatever the medium in which it will be used, avoid graphics that are crammed with too much information. The reader or viewer should be able to look at the graphic and take away one basic idea. 
    • Graphics need to be used  transparently and accurately to enhance understanding. 
      Think of a graphic as a highway sign - the driver doesn’t get a chance to study it as they are driving, so the information has to be clear and easily absorbed. 

      Imagine you have a story that says a city’s annual budget is twice as large as it was 10 years ago. A bar graph charting the size of the budget for each of the last 10 years would be an easy way to make that clear. 

      In a story about city business development crowding out residents, you could list the number of apartments and office buildings in the area. However, it would be more effective to create a pie chart showing the relationship.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Journalists use data-sharing tools, such as internal wikis and shared databases in news organisations.
    • Crowdsourcing draws news and information direct from communities. 
    • The distributed reporting model, requires a news organization to go public with a story idea and allow readers to assist in the development of the story.
    • Social and independent news media, is posing a challenge to the mainstream, corporate-sponsored news.
    • Technological advances have led to changes in how people consume and share news. 
    • A blog helps a journalist to publish information outside of the traditional news cycle.
    • The goal of blogging is to publish information quickly and concisely. It allows for instant feedback and a conversational style.
    • Tips for interviews: write a script; prepare your voice; use operative words; maintain a conversational tone; listen; don't impose your own point of view.
    • Podcasting is the distribution of audio files over the Internet. 
    • The use of multimedia (graphics, photos, video, audio) should enhance the understanding of a story and complement the text - not be a distraction from it.
    • If visuals tell the “what” of the story; words tell the “why.” 
    • There are two main types of video assignments: documentaries and breaking news.

  • Module Three Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Detail the essential elements of a news package.
    • Identify the elements of online writing structures.
    • Define what is meant by 'fair use' and plagiarism.
    • Outline script writing techniques.
    • Explain vision, value and ethics statements in media organizations.
    • List the elements of SMART objectives.

    • Are you in control of your news organization’s editorial agenda? 
      You may think you are, but an examination of what prompts or stimulates you to cover news may reveal flaws in your news strategy. 

      It could be that the majority of the news you cover on any given day is directly or indirectly controlled by others. A simple forward planning strategy, based on original, issue-led journalism, can reverse this. 

      Too many media organizations depend on the first five sources. The sixth is common to all. However, a responsible media organization that exists to inform the public debate with thorough, objective, fair and accurate journalism, will spend time investing in the last six sources of news.
      Are you in control of your news organization’s editorial agenda?

    • The challenge for all news organizations, whether they are global broadcasters or local newspapers, is to take control and set a news agenda producing and increasing the amount of original journalism.

      The first step is to set aside resources for planning. It will mean reassigning some staff and encouraging them to invest their time in producing original, investigative journalism that focuses on the target audience.

      It could be that the majority of the news you cover on any given day is directly or indirectly controlled by others. A simple forward planning strategy, based on original, issue-led journalism, can reverse this. 

      Too many media organizations depend on the first five sources. The sixth is common to all. However, a responsible media organization that exists to inform the public debate with thorough, objective, fair and accurate journalism, will spend time investing in the last six sources of news.

    • Knowing your audience, understanding the issues they face, and being aware of what they think about society, are important factors for fine-tuning what you offer in order to better inform public debate.

      That is why it’s necessary to be thorough in researching who you aim to serve, with your content. 

      It requires talking to the audience, asking their opinions on your output, and then analyzing the results and feeding all the information back into the overall strategy. The purpose of audience research:

      - It helps to produce better content focused on audience needs.
      - It helps to continually improve and maintain content as relevant.
      - It generates new ideas for producing audience-related material.
      - It offers sales and marketing teams the information they need to try to monetize content.
      - It highlights new business development opportunities.

    • Surveys need to be factored into the overall strategy and plotted on a calendar so that you can make regular comparisons about performance and how the audience is changing.

      Some media organizations have the luxury of being able to afford research teams whose job it is to plan campaigns to monitor the audience response, but for many the research has to be provided by using existing resources.

      For example, the news department might be set the objective to break seven original news stories a week. To achieve that objective, each reporter might be set the objective to break at least one original news story a month. 

      To help both the journalists and the news department achieve their objectives, the editor might decide to carry out audience surveys to try to find out more about the issues that most concern viewers, and explore ways of investigating those stories.

      It requires talking to the audience, asking their opinions on your output, and then analyzing the results and feeding all the information back into the overall strategy. The purpose of audience research:

      - It helps to produce better content focused on audience needs.
      - It helps to continually improve and maintain content as relevant.
      - It generates new ideas for producing audience-related material.
      - It offers sales and marketing teams the information they need to try to monetize content.
      - It highlights new business development opportunities.

    • SURVEYS
      Surveys need to be factored into the overall strategy and plotted on a calendar so that you can make regular comparisons about performance and how the audience is changing.

      Some media organizations have the luxury of being able to afford research teams whose job it is to plan campaigns to monitor the audience response, but for many the research has to be provided by using existing resources.

      For example, the news department might be set the objective to break seven original news stories a week. To achieve that objective, each reporter might be set the objective to break at least one original news story a month. 

      To help both the journalists and the news department achieve their objectives, the editor might decide to carry out audience surveys to try to find out more about the issues that most concern viewers, and explore ways of investigating those stories.

    • Radio, television, and online, or Web-based journalism are specialized forms with unique demands and requirements.

      Broadcast journalists use not only words, but also sound and video in constructing their stories.

      What they write must be written to be heard, not read, by the audience. Like their TV counterparts, online journalists can include sound and video in their stories, as well as interactive elements that allow a reader to explore the story at his or her own pace.
      Radio, television, and online, or Web-based journalism are specialized forms with unique demands and requirements.

      Broadcast journalists use not only words, but also sound and video in constructing their stories.

      What they write must be written to be heard, not read, by the audience. Like their TV counterparts, online journalists can include sound and video in their stories, as well as interactive elements that allow a reader to explore the story at his or her own pace.
    • The basic broadcast story forms are the reader story, the V/O or voice over, and the wrap or package. 

      A reader story is a story without additional sound bites or video, usually presented by the newscaster in the studio. 

      A V/O is a television term for a story told with video but without sound bites. The newsreader will read the script for the story while the video is playing. 

      A complete story by a reporter is called a wrap or a package.

      What they write must be written to be heard, not read, by the audience. Like their TV counterparts, online journalists can include sound and video in their stories, as well as interactive elements that allow a reader to explore the story at his or her own pace.

    • The basic broadcast story forms are the reader story, the V/O or voice over, and the wrap or package. 

      A reader story is a story without additional sound bites or video, usually presented by the newscaster in the studio. 

      A V/O is a television term for a story told with video but without sound bites. The newsreader will read the script for the story while the video is playing. 

      A complete story by a reporter is called a wrap or a package.

  • Lesson Summary

    • News organizations must be able to produce interesting, original journalism for diverse audiences, using a variety of media, if they are to survive in the current market.
    • Structure, timing, and letting an interview breathe are essential elements of ensuring a TV, radio or online news package works.
    • Online news stories must take advantage of interactive digital media and allow readers to become active participants in a story.
    • Plagiarism and copyright laws restrict how peoples' work can be used in journalistic stories. 
    • Being impartial, is an essential approach for robust news coverage.
    • Knowing your audience and understanding the issues are important factors in deciding what to offer.
    • If content is not being delivered in the right place at the right time, it’s not being strategically delivered.
    • Focus groups, surveys and usability studies, help journalists to deliver timely and interesting content to users.
    • News organisations communicate their vision, values and pledge to audiences, by setting their objectives first.
    • Broadcast journalists use words, sound and video (scripts) in their stories, which have to be written in simple and easy-to-understand language.
    • According to the 'pyramid' structure of news reporting, you begin with the hook or essence of the story and gradually add further details as you go along. This technique appeals to a broader audience. 
    • The digital savvy news consumer is a 'superuser' - empowered with the tools to choose, create and share information. Journalists and news organisations ignore this at their peril.
